header.title: HOW IS THE HUMAN BEING MADE UP?

central_thesis: The human being is fundamentally constituted by a trinity of interdependent principles: the Physical Body, an intermediary principle known as the Astral Body, and the Immortal Spirit. This tripartite division is a universal law reflected in the micro- and macrocosm, crucial for understanding human faculties, organic functions, and spiritual development.

structure_content.summary: Addresses fundamental questions regarding human composition, refuting reductionist views of man as solely a physical body or a simple body-spirit duality. It introduces the Western Christian occult tradition's perspective, emphasizing a multi-layered human constitution.

Presents three fundamental questions about human composition, arguing against the physical body as the sole source of faculties and against a simple body-spirit duality. It asserts that an intermediary principle exists, leading to the conclusion that man is made up of three principles, not just two or one.

Describes the physical body's three main centers (Abdomen, Chest, Head) and their associated limbs and functions. It illustrates how this physical structure itself reflects a 'Trinity' and how these centers, through their respective organs, perform specialized physiological processes largely independent of conscious will, constituting the 'Animal-Man'.

Identifies the 'Astral Body' as the crucial intermediary principle, often called 'anima' by Saint Paul or 'Plastic Mediator' by Hermetic philosophers. This principle, described as the 'concealed worker' or 'horse' of the human being, directs vegetative and organic life through the sympathetic nervous system and its plexuses, operating independently of conscious awareness. It is responsible for healing, regeneration, and the maintenance of organic functions.

Defines the 'Spirit-Man' as the conscious being or 'coachman' who, though less physically strong, possesses intelligence and directs the 'Animal-Man' (Astral Body) and the physical body. It explains how the Spirit-Man operates through specific facial senses (taste, smell, hearing) and expressions to govern choices related to food, breathing, and the reception of higher faculties, thus asserting control over the lower principles.

Expands on the physical body's three centers, correlating them with three 'psychic centers' or intellectual manifestations: Instinct (physical center/sensation), Intuition (astral center/emotion), and Idea (psychic/spirit center/emotion). The text posits that the Spirit, through will, can counteract impulses from lower centers, requiring training and self-discipline.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Auras of the Human Being
structure_content.summary: Introduces the concept of 'auras' as invisible radiations associated with each of the three principles (physical, astral, spiritual). These auras invisibly record an individual's thoughts, actions, and character, perceptible to 'trained souls' or clairvoyants, influencing phenomena like sudden liking/disliking and intuitions.

Provides a syncretic overview of how various esoteric and religious traditions (Egyptian, Kabalistic, Pythagorean, Hermetic, Hindu, Chinese, Saint Paul) have classified the human being. It demonstrates how seemingly disparate systems, whether ternary, quinary, septenary, or nonary, can be reduced to the core three principles (Physical, Astral, Spiritual) for a coherent understanding.

Reiterates the core thesis that man is a 'Trinity synthesized into an admirable Unity,' comprised of a physical body, an astral body, and an immortal Spirit. It emphasizes the critical role of the astral body as the intermediary principle and the necessity of understanding this tripartite structure for addressing profound questions about human nature.

key_concepts.definition: The fundamental division of the human being into Physical Body, an Intermediary Principle (Astral Body/Soul), and Immortal Spirit. This ternary model is presented as a universal law of nature.

The material, mortal vehicle of human existence, structured into three major centers (Abdomen, Chest, Head) each with corresponding physiological functions and limbs, reflecting the universal law of Trinity.

key_concepts.term: Astral Body (Anima, Luminous Body, Plastic Mediator, Animal-Man)
key_concepts.definition: The intermediary, animating principle responsible for organic life, cell regeneration, and physiological functions via the sympathetic nervous system and its plexuses. It is the 'concealed worker' or 'horse' of the human machine, acting independently of conscious will for basic life processes, and can be projected outside the body.

The conscious, intelligent, and directing principle, acting as the 'coachman' of the human being. It governs higher faculties, directs the Astral Body and Physical Body, and can exert will to overcome lower impulses, largely functioning through the cephalic nervous system and facial senses.

Correlations of the three physical centers with intellectual manifestations: the Physical center manifests Instinct with sensation, the Astral center manifests Intuition with emotion, and the Psychic/Spirit center manifests Idea with emotion. Each is a domain where the will can act or where impulses originate.

Invisible radiations surrounding the human being, specific to each of the three principles (physical, astral, spiritual). These auras are a record of an individual's thoughts and actions, perceptible to a 'trained soul' or occultist, influencing subtle interactions and perceptions.

A faculty developed by 'trained souls' to perceive the history and characteristics of objects or individuals through their invisible radiations or 'auras,' typically by placing the object on the forehead.
Refers to the part of the human being governed by the Astral Body and its functions, particularly the unconscious and automatic organic processes.

practical_system.description: While not a grimoire or explicit ritual manual, the text outlines a foundational metaphysical and anatomical system upon which practical esoteric work is built. The core 'practicality' lies in understanding the interplay of the three principles for self-mastery. The Spirit (coachman) is to direct the Astral Body (horse) and Physical Body (carriage), asserting conscious will over instinctual and emotional impulses. This requires 'appropriate exercises and training' to accustom the organs serving the Spirit to function as 'regulators and leaders,' preventing spiritual 'inactivity' and 'crushing reactions from below by putting into action forces from above'. The development of 'Psychometry' through training is also mentioned as a practical skill for perceiving subtle realities.

relevant_quotes.text: Man is therefore made up of THREE PRINCIPLES: 1. The material physical body. 2. An intermediary principle. 3. The immortal Spirit.
It is the concealed worker of the human being, it is the horse of the organism of which the physical body is the carriage, and the conscious being is the coachman.
Physical body, Soul, Spirit, such is the trinity of the constitution of the human being, which we have tried to explain to the best of our ability.
The three component principles in man: the physical Principle, the Astral Principle and the Spiritual Principle. We will refer to them as: PHYSICAL, ASTRAL, SPIRITUAL.
The forces generated by man are, in the final analysis, only the products of refraction which have come from the divine plan.

critical_analysis.relevance: Papus's 'How is the Human Being Made Up?' is a foundational text within French Occultism and Martinism, serving as an accessible introduction to complex occult anatomy. It articulates a tripartite human constitution (Physical, Astral, Spirit) through a comparative approach, drawing parallels with Egyptian, Kabalistic, Hermetic, Pythagorean, and Christian Gnostic traditions. This syncretic method attempts to unify diverse esoteric philosophies under a coherent, universally applicable model. The emphasis on the intermediary Astral Body, and its functions via the sympathetic nervous system, provides a pseudoscientific framework typical of late 19th/early 20th-century occultism, linking physiological observation with esoteric principles. Its enduring relevance lies in its influence on subsequent Western esoteric thought and its clear, methodical presentation of concepts like the aura and psychic centers, which became integral to modern occult practice.
critical_analysis.target_audience: This work is explicitly aimed at 'beginners in occult studies' and 'everybody' seeking a clear, non-dogmatic understanding of human constitution from a Western Christian occult perspective. It is designed for 'mystical enlightenment' and serves as an introductory guide for those who are new to esoteric concepts, seeking to provide a factual and speculative-free foundation for further study in occultism, as indicated by the 'Martinist Tradition' series context.
